title: Whirligig Experiment on low friction surface

content.question:
An experiment is performed using the apparatus above. A small disk of mass m1 on a frictionless table is attached to one end of a string. The string passes through a hole in the table and an attached narrow, vertical plastic tube. An object of mass m2 is hung at the other end of the string. A student holding the tube makes the disk rotate in a circle of constant radius r, while another student measures the period P.

(a) Derive the equation <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>P</mi> <mo> </mo> <mo>=</mo> <mo> </mo> <mn>2</mn> <mi>π</mi> <msqrt> <mrow> <mfrac> <mrow> <msub> <mi>m</mi> <mn>1</mn> </msub> <mi>r</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <msub> <mi>m</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msub> <mi>g</mi> </mrow> </mfrac> </mrow> </msqrt> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@43AF@</annotation> </semantics> </math> that relates P and m2.

The procedure is repeated, and the period P is determined for four different values of m2, where m1 = 0.012 kg and r = 0.80 m. The data, which are presented below, can be used to compute an experimental value for g.

<math> <semantics> <mrow> <msub> <mi>m</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msub> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mi>k</mi> <mi>g</mi> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3BBC@</annotation> </semantics> </math>
 0.020
 0.040
 0.060
 0.080

P (s)
 1.40
 1.05
 0.80
 0.75

(b) What quantities should be graphed to yield a straight line with a slope that could be used to determine g ?

(c) On the grid below, plot the quantities determined in part (b), label the axes, and draw the best-fit line to the data. You may use the blank rows above to record any values you may need to calculate.

(d) Use your graph to calculate the experimental value of g.

frqParts.text:
An experiment is performed using the apparatus above. A small disk of mass m1 on a frictionless table is attached to one end of a string. The string passes through a hole in the table and an attached narrow, vertical plastic tube. An object of mass m2 is hung at the other end of the string. A student holding the tube makes the disk rotate in a circle of constant radius r, while another student measures the period P.

(a) Derive the equation <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>P</mi> <mo> </mo> <mo>=</mo> <mo> </mo> <mn>2</mn> <mi>π</mi> <msqrt> <mrow> <mfrac> <mrow> <msub> <mi>m</mi> <mn>1</mn> </msub> <mi>r</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <msub> <mi>m</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msub> <mi>g</mi> </mrow> </mfrac> </mrow> </msqrt> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@43AF@</annotation> </semantics> </math> that relates P and m2.

The procedure is repeated, and the period P is determined for four different values of m2, where m1 = 0.012 kg and r = 0.80 m. The data, which are presented below, can be used to compute an experimental value for g.

<math> <semantics> <mrow> <msub> <mi>m</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msub> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mi>k</mi> <mi>g</mi> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3BBC@</annotation> </semantics> </math>
 0.020
 0.040
 0.060
 0.080

P (s)
 1.40
 1.05
 0.80
 0.75

(b) What quantities should be graphed to yield a straight line with a slope that could be used to determine g ?

(c) On the grid below, plot the quantities determined in part (b), label the axes, and draw the best-fit line to the data. You may use the blank rows above to record any values you may need to calculate.

(d) Use your graph to calculate the experimental value of g.

skill.text: 1.B: Create quantitative graphs with appropriate scales and units, including plotting data.
